results.title: People and Work

group_works.title: Steel (TEFC)
group_works.creator_credit: Gwynn Pritchard, Open University and BBC-TV

results.title: Steel (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Gwynn Pritchard, Open University and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “People and Work”.
Looks at the effect that modernisation of the work processes has had on the industrial relations and the experience of work and its consequences for the traditional skills of steel making. Shot entirely at the BSC Anchor Plant at Scunthorpe, the largest and most up-to-date steel works in Europe, it concentrates on the steel workers themselves. A case study for the students of the sociology of work.

results.title: People's century: 1900-1999
results.brief_description: ‘People’s century’ is a unique combination of rare archival footage and personal testimony that chronicles the 20th century. Through fascinating eyewitness accounts, this acclaimed BBC, WGBH/Boston co production examines how political, economic and technological changes transformed the lives of ordinary people. There are 26 episodes in the series (included on 8 tapes).

results.title: 1975: War of the flea: 1979: god fights back: 1989: people power: 1997: fast forward
results.creator_credit: Archie Baron, Angus MacQueen, Ben Loeterman, Dominic Ozanne, Bill Treharne Jones, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “People’s century: 1900-1999”.
This tape contains episodes twenty three to twenty six of the ‘People’s century 1900-1999’ series. 1975: WAR OF THE FLEA; success by guerilla fighters in Cuba, Vietnam and Afghanistan are used to illustrate how minority groups were able to overthrown government authorities, and are united by their religious idealogy and the uneasy peace that followed their actions. Narrated by Sean Barrett. 1979: GOD FIGHTS BACK; the secular liberalism of many Middle Eastern, African and Asian countries is rejected as the Ayatollah Khomeini’s Iranian revolution inspires Muslims to seek fundamentalist Islamic governments. Narrated by Sean Barrett. 1989: PEOPLE POWER; from the 1980 strike in Poland’s Gdansk Shipyard to the army’s attempt to lay siege to the Russian White House, eyewitnesses from an historic era recall the fall of the Eastern Bloc. Narrated by Veronika Hyks. 1997: FAST FORWARD; the collapse of Communism and the end of the Cold War heralds a new era of global capitalism. It also brought with it a bloody price, as resurging nationalism and old animosity brought forward ethnic violence, and an increasing divide between rich and poor brought social unrest. What will the twenty first century bring? Narrated by Sean Barrett.

results.title: 1956: endangered planet: 1963: picture power: 1954: living longer
results.creator_credit: Peter Ceresole, James Devinney, Gabrielle Osrin, Max Whitby, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “People’s century: 1900-1999”.
This tape contains episodes seventeen to nineteen of the ‘People’s century 1900-1999’ series. “1959: endangered planet”; post war prosperity had been reached, but at a price. In Minimata, Japan, people become contaminated by mercury poisoning from a nearby factory, while across America pesticides are sprayed on crops to kill insects. Rachel Carson releases the contentious book “Silent Spring”, challenging the notion that pesticide is not harmful. Her novel is only the start of a long and slow process to combat the initial belief that smog, contamination, dirt and pollution are necessary by-products to industrial prosperity. Greenpeace is formed and Environmental Protection agencies established to counteract the balance between people and the environment. Narrated by Sean Barrett. “1963: picture power”; television arrives and brings with it the power of instant communication. Different schools of thought exist internationally as to the potential power of television - public service, political propaganda, or advertising tool. As millions of people across the world began to see the same events unfold at the same time, ultimately entertainment would win out. Narrated by Sean Barrett. “1954: living longer”; the 1950s saw a marked increase in health and wellbeing in developed countries. National Health Services and Social Security were established with a charter of preventative health as well as a concerted effort to try and cure the epidemics which had ailed many, such as polio and tuberculosis. On an international scale the World Health Organisation is established to monitor the health of the world, in particular in developing countries with diseases such as smallpox. With the increased survival rate however came an inevitable by-product of longevity - over population. Narrated by Sean Barrett.

results.title: 1949: Great leap: 1968: new release: 1970: half of the people
results.creator_credit: Anne Moir, Lisa Jones, Mark J. Davis, Angela Holdsworth, Jennifer Clayton, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “People’s century: 1900-1999”.
This tape contains episodes twenty to twenty two of the ‘People’s century 1900-1999’ series. “1949: great leap”; in 1949 Chairman Mao heads a resounding victory to Communism and the beginning of a Cultural Revolution intended to end the social divide between rich and poor. Throughout his reign Mao would gain support from the peasants and students, but at a high cost to human life through natural disasters such as famines, and persecution for those who did not follow party policy. Only death would stop the master plan. Narrated by Veronika Hyks. “1968: new release”; a generation of baby boomers brought up to “respect their elders” become teenagers and with the transition comes a new freedom as reflected in music, film and advertising at the time. Resistors to authoritarian rule became international heroes and youth across the world became involved in draft resistance to the Vietnam War. It was the start of a decade of student activism across Britain, Europe and America concerning issues such as the environment, women’s rights and gay liberation. Narrated by Sean Barrett. “1970: half the people”; women achieve a sense of purpose as they fill the roles of men who have left to fight, roles which do not seem destined to continue as the men return. A post-war generation of women take up the fight for equality and recall the battle for equal pay and opportunities and the sexual freedom obtained with the development of the new birth control pill. The situation would not be the same for women in third world countries such as Asia and Africa. Narrated by Sean Barrett.

results.title: 1945: Fallout. 1951: Asia rising. 1957: Skin deep
results.creator_credit: Marcus Kiggell, Bill Treharne Jones, Charles Furneaux, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “People’s century: 1900-1999”.
This tape contains episodes fourteen to sixteen of the ‘People’s century 1900-1999’ series. “1945: fallout”; a nuclear bomb ends the war and signals a new age for society - the nuclear age. Eager to posses nuclear weapons of their own, Stalin institutes secret factories to manufacture nuclear weapons, but Russia is only one of the many countries who now have their own armament of nuclear weapons. America and Britain promote the benefits of this “new” power, encouraging people to make the most of its benefits as nuclear plants are built across the world. With this scientific progress however comes suspicion and fear, thoughts which prove founded as the side effect of radiation become known and disasters like Chernobyl have far reaching repercussions. Narrated by Sean Barrett. “1951: Asia rising”; Japan becomes the first of many Asian countries to rebuild after the war and match Western standards. Post war success is achieved by a strong work ethic and high standard of education, the paternalism of large companies who provided living arrangements for their employees, a ban on imports, and strong authoritarian rule. The pinnacle of Japan’s progress is reached when they host the Olympic Games in Tokyo. The Tiger economies have arrived. Narrated by Sean Barrett. “1957: skin deep”; in the deep south of America in the 1950s, state laws enforce segregation between black and white. In South Africa the same laws apply and are enforced by the minority ruling Afrikaans who institutionalise apartheid in the late 1940s. Resistance in America comes in the form of the civil rights movement, while in South Africa the African National Campaign (ANC) begins to take form under the leadership of Nelson Mandela, who is quickly imprisoned, thus contributing to his cult status as a civil rights activist. Narrated by Veronika Hyks.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Marcus Kiggell, Bill Treharne Jones, Charles Furneaux, WGBH (Boston) and BBC

Post war success is achieved by a strong work ethic and high standard of education, the paternalism of large companies who provided living arrangements for their employees, a ban on imports, and strong authoritarian rule. The pinnacle of Japan’s progress is reached when they host the Olympic Games in Tokyo. The Tiger economies have arrived. Narrated by Sean Barrett. “1957: skin deep”; in the deep south of America in the 1950s, state laws enforce segregation between black and white. In South Africa the same laws apply and are enforced by the minority ruling Afrikaans who institutionalise apartheid in the late 1940s. Resistance in America comes in the form of the civil rights movement, while in South Africa the African National Campaign (ANC) begins to take form under the leadership of Nelson Mandela, who is quickly imprisoned, thus contributing to his cult status as a civil rights activist. Narrated by Veronika Hyks.
description_for_label:
Episode number 5 of Series “People’s century: 1900-1999”.
This tape contains episodes fourteen to sixteen of the ‘People’s century 1900-1999’ series. “1945: fallout”; a nuclear bomb ends the war and signals a new age for society - the nuclear age. Eager to posses nuclear weapons of their own, Stalin institutes secret factories to manufacture nuclear weapons, but Russia is only one of the many countries who now have their own armament of nuclear weapons. America and Britain promote the benefits of this “new” power, encouraging people to make the most of its benefits as nuclear plants are built across the world. With this scientific progress however comes suspicion and fear, thoughts which prove founded as the side effect of radiation become known and disasters like Chernobyl have far reaching repercussions. Narrated by Sean Barrett. “1951: Asia rising”; Japan becomes the first of many Asian countries to rebuild after the war and match Western standards. Post war success is achieved by a strong work ethic and high standard of education, the paternalism of large companies who provided living arrangements for their employees, a ban on imports, and strong authoritarian rule. The pinnacle of Japan’s progress is reached when they host the Olympic Games in Tokyo. The Tiger economies have arrived. Narrated by Sean Barrett. “1957: skin deep”; in the deep south of America in the 1950s, state laws enforce segregation between black and white. In South Africa the same laws apply and are enforced by the minority ruling Afrikaans who institutionalise apartheid in the late 1940s. Resistance in America comes in the form of the civil rights movement, while in South Africa the African National Campaign (ANC) begins to take form under the leadership of Nelson Mandela, who is quickly imprisoned, thus contributing to his cult status as a civil rights activist. Narrated by Veronika Hyks.

results.title: 1945: Brave new world. 1948: Boomtime. 1947: Freedom now
results.creator_credit: Jennifer Clayton, Sally Doganis, Angus MacQueen, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “People’s century: 1900-1999”.
This tape contains episodes eleven to thirteen of the ‘People’s century 1900-1999’ series. “1945: brave new world”; post war euphoria gives way to a new war - the Cold War, as the Communist East and the Capitalist West are separated by the Iron Curtain. The Occupied powers begin deciding how Europe will look following the war and Churchill visits America, warning them of the terror rising in the Soviet sphere. Berlin represents a pocket of capitalism in the communist landscape. When Russia gains itself an atomic bomb, Stalin has all the power he needs. Narrated by Veronika Hyks. “1948: boomtime”; the Marshall plan moves into full swing as America make a concerted financial effort to rebuild Europe after the war. Heavy industry is re invigorated and Europeans visit America to learn valuable lessons in productivity. As time passes confidence builds and Europe begins exporting back to America on their home turf. The consumer society would rides on a wave of mass prosperity until 1973 when the cheap oil required to facilitate progress is no longer available. Narrated by Sean Barrett. “1947: freedom now”; when Gandhi showed the world how the masses could successfully defy their colonial masters, thousands across Africa and Asia joined the fight for control of their own destinies. Africa is paid particular attention to in this episode - as the European colonial powers retreat, a lack of resources and the language barriers left by imposed European boundaries detract from the peace process. Freedom would come at the cost of civil war. Narrated by Veronika Hyks.

results.title: 1929: breadline: 1933: master race: 1939: total war (D)
results.creator_credit: John Birdcut, Jonathan Lewis, Archie Baron, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “People’s century: 1900-1999”.
This tape contains episodes eight to ten of the ‘People’s century 1900-1999’ series. “1929: breadline”; the material prosperity of the 1920s comes to a grinding halt with the stock market crash of 1929. The aftershocks are felt worldwide, with countries relying on trade with America suffering most. With poverty came disillusionment, impatience with governments who were willing to let the Depression run its course and a shift to political ideals that were opposed to capitalism. In America, Roosevelt “saves” his people by instituting a scheme of public works - it took a war to involve masses of people in the workforce again. Narrated by Sean Barrett. “1933: master race”; the Nazis march into power in 1933 with a victory to the National Socialist Party. Racial purity becomes the objective to pursue at all costs as Jews, gypsies, homosexuals, black people and the handicapped are considered a threat to the master race and to be persecuted and eradicated. When Hitler invades Poland in 1938 in a bid for expansion, war breaks out. Narrated by Veronika Hyks. “1939: total war”; the nature of war is changing as civilians become a pawn in a bloody affair, under threat of attacks from the sky and on the ground. China suffers greatly at the hands of the Japanese, while in Leningrad, Russians suffer a similar fate at the hands of the Germans. Millions of lives are lost to starvation and bombing. Narrated by Veronika Hyks.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Birdcut, Jonathan Lewis, Archie Baron, WGBH (Boston) and BBC

results.title: 1900: Age of hope. 1914: Killing fields. 1917: Red flag
results.creator_credit: Bill Treharne Jones, Jonathan Lewis, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “People’s century: 1900-1999”.
This tape contains the first three episodes of the ‘People’s century 1900-1999’ series. “1900: age of hope”; as the century begins, a trade exhibition in Paris captures the optimism of the new century as the powerful countries of the world showcase their material progress. The state funeral of Queen Victoria in 1901 undermines progress however, reminding the country of its ties with the old order of European dynasties. Russia too is caught firmly in the grip of autocracy, leading many Europeans to migrate to America. Mass literacy vastly changes the political awareness of ordinary citizens and newspapers bring politics to the masses in Britain and the United States. The suffragette movement is also in full swing, while the colonies work towards self government. Europe is caught up in strategic alliances, a situation which ensures world involvement should a war begin. Narrated by Sean Barrett. “1914: killing fields”; Europe and Germany are drawn into a new kind of war - an industrialized war in which logistics and machine guns make a devastating and significant debut. There is the first full scale project of propaganda against the Germans, as battles at the Somme, Verdun and Ypres facilitate the slaughter of thousands of soldiers on both sides of the battle. The war ends in 1918 with an armistice and no clear victor, as well as a new distrust of public figureheads who allowed the slaughter to continue. It seems doubtful the world can return to the idyll of 1914. Narrated by Veronica Hyks. “917: red flag”; in the Soviet Union the people finally make a move to overthrown the tsar, Nicholas II, and put an end to autocratic power. An uprising, led by the Marxist socialist Lenin succeeds in overthrowing the tsar and his family. He replaces it with another system which would have international repercussion, Communism, which appealed to America during the Depression due to its productivity and opportunities for women. Narrated by Sean Barrett.
